title: 114_hr5305
content: The Act titled "Ste. Genevieve National Historic Site Establishment Act of 2016" defines key terms like Historic District, Historic Site, Map, Secretary, and State. It establishes the Ste. Genevieve National Historic Site. The Ste. Genevieve National Historic Site is established to preserve French settlement themes, architecture, and farming on the frontier. The site will not be established until sufficient land is acquired and a written agreement is in place. The boundaries of the Ste. Genevieve National Historic Site are depicted on a map available for public inspection. The Secretary has the authority to acquire land within the site through donation, purchase, or exchange. The Secretary can revise the Historic Site boundary to include acquired property. The administration of the site follows specific laws and a management plan must be developed within 3 years. The Secretary must prepare a general management plan for the Historic Site within 3 years of funds availability, following specific laws. The plan must be submitted to Congress upon completion. Additionally, interpretative tours and educational programs can be provided at related historic and cultural sites within the Historic District. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with owners of nationally significant properties in the Historic Site or District to improve and restore the properties, providing access for visitors. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with property owners for the purposes of conducting visitors through the property and interpreting it for the public. The Federal share of the total cost of activities under the agreement shall not exceed 50%, and the non-Federal share may be in the form of donated property, goods, or services. No changes or alterations can be made to the property covered by the agreement without the Secretary's approval. Any payment by the Secretary under this subsection shall be subject to an agreement that the conversion, use, or disposal of a property for purposes contrary to the purposes of this section shall entitle the United States to reimbursement. The Secretary is not authorized to take financial responsibility for the Historic District's operation, maintenance, or management. SEC. 4. Land acquisition; no buffer zones. The Secretary can acquire land within the Historic Site and District by donation or exchange only, without condemnation. No private or non-Federal public property can be included without owner consent. No buffer zones are created outside the Historic Site and District. Activities or uses within the Historic Site and District do not restrict the same activities or uses outside the area.
